726091f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Boulevard - 8th Street
726091f-a.text:
Astoria Boulevard, north side, between 79th and 80th Streets,
showing the C. Luyster house of 1852, L. Douglas was the owner in
1873 and F. Conover in 1896.
April 1923
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MA~ BE REPRODUCED

726067f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Boulevard - 8th Street
726067f-a.text:
Astoria Boulevard, between Third and First Streets, viewing
northward aross the scrap metal dumps on the south side of the
thoroughfare,toward the buildings on the north side. View three
shows an old dwelling, Drobahly dating back to pre-Revolutionary
days. The vantage point is the shore of Hallets Cove.
P. L. Sperr  Larch 11, 1931
NO REPRODUTTIONS  Views 1,2,3:

726102f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Boulevard - 8th Street
726102f-a.text:
Astoria Squsre -- point of intersection of Astoria
Boulevard, 27th Avenue, Newtown Avenue, and 21st Street
-- viewing west from where the Newtown Avenue trolley
tracks (lower left corner) join those on Astoria Boule-
vard. The latter thoroughfare bends southwestward to the
left of the four-story building; to the right is 27th
Avenue, running west from 21st Street.
P. L. Sperr  March 13, 1931
NO REPRODUCEIONS

726088f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Boulevard - 8th Street
726088f-a.text:
Astoria Boulevard, aouth side, in the 75th Street line,
showing a building of modern origin located on land belonging to
J. L. Riker from 1873 to 1896.
April 1923
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED

726093f-c.title: Queens: Astoria Boulevard - 8th Street
726093f-c.text:
Astoria Boulevard, north side, west from 88th Street,
over Jacksons Mill Creek, and showing an old farmhouse
nestling among the trees at 87th Street. This land is part
of the former Kouvenhoven estate.
P. L. Sperr  October 19, 1935
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 1,2,3

726058f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Boulevard - 8th Street
726058f-a.text:
Astoria, Queens: Shown is a general view of Astoria,
looking southwestward from the Triborough Bridge. The
thoroughfare is 21st Street, running south from Hoyt Avenue.
In the background is the Cueensboro Bridge (left) and the
Mid-Manhattan skyline.
P. L. Sperr  July 25, 1936
NO REPRODUCTIONS
